text: (upbeat music)

- [Narrator] The new
Bundesliga Match Fact,

pressure handling, shows how
often a player can escape
from significant pressure situations
without losing the ball.
There are four ways of doing this.

Passing, dribbling, getting
fouled, or shooting.

How often a players successfully
executes one of these ways
is shown in the escape rate,
the main KPI of pressure handling.
Additionally, exceptional performance

that can be delivered
despite the high pressure
will be shown via the offensive dual rate,
the completed pass rate under pressure,
shot efficiency, as well as goals scored.

Above all, creative
players in central midfield

regularly operates between
the lines of the opponents,
and are therefore automatically exposed
to high pressure from the opposition.

One player who primarily
escapes pressure situations
by passing is Frankfurt's Mario Gotze.

Here he's put under
pressure on the touch line

by three goal players,
but he keeps a cool head,
looks out for his teammate,

and resolves the situation
with a ball over the top.

His escape rate up to
match day five was 52%.

That means he'd been able to
retain possession for his team

in every second match
situation so far in the season.

Escaping pressure with
few touches of the ball
is an art in itself.
One of the best players in this area

is Bayern's Joshua Kimmich,
with his assured passing game.
The Germany international
prevails 7 out 10 pressure situations,
one of the top values in the Bundesliga.
He's often only stoppable through fouls
when in these pressure situations.
Jeremie Frimpong of Bayer Leverkusen
is also often put under pressure,

but deals with it in his
own way through dribbling.
Thanks to his pace and mobility,
he often looks to take on the man
and is not put off by being pressed
by several opponents simultaneously.
Thanks to his skill as a sprinter,

he can often only be stopped
in this case by a foul,

which is recorded as a
challenge won for him.

Consequentially, he had a
success rate of 67% in tackles.

The fourth way of escaping
pressure situations is shooting.
Union Berlin forward, Sheraldo Becker,
has been the best in the division at this
after the first five match days.

Against RB Leipzig,
he's put under pressure
in the tightest of spaces
by three opponents in the penalty box
and is still able to shoot.

Despite the goal probability
being 11%, he scores.

- [Announcer] It's a
masterclass of Union Berlin!
Becker finds the top corner.
- [Narrator] Pressure handling,

the new Bundesliga Match
Fact powered by AWS
is impressive in showing fans

how well a player can
escape a pressure situation
without losing the ball.
The higher the escape rate,
the better the player deals with pressure
from the opposition.

At the same time, it also
highlights special performances
that the player can deliver.
